text: I love how Notion allows me to manage my notes, daily tasks, projects, and personal documentation all in one place. It serves as my hub for planning, writing, storing resources, and collaborating on short-term projects, making it an indispensable knowledge base. The high level of customization available for pages and database views, coupled with a clean, distraction-free interface, enhances my experience significantly. The use of templates is a huge time saver, especially for managing projects, planning content, and tracking habits. Linking pages and databases is intuitive and ensures information is easily accessible. Notion’s ability to replace multiple apps like documents, spreadsheets, task managers, and note-taking applications into a single workspace helps me stay organized and reduces the clutter, allowing me to maintain everything cohesively without the hassle of switching between different apps. I find Notion can be overwhelming at first due to its many features. The application can become slow, especially when handling heavy pages on large databases. I also see room for improvement in the offline mode as not everything syncs properly, which affects usability. Formatting on the mobile version is more challenging compared to the desktop version, and the reminders and basic functionality feel quite limited compared to dedicated tools for those tasks. Excellent All-in-One productive space for Project & Design Work

What I absolutely love about Notion is how ridiculously flexible it is. It's not just a note app; it's the one central place where I can also organise and develop from initial client brainstorms to final portfolio showcases.It seriously cuts down on bouncing between different apps and makes managing my creative workflow seamless. While the core product is outstanding, its offline capabilities continue to be a significant drawback. Whenever I experience weak Wi-Fi or am traveling, trying to access or update important information becomes extremely slow or sometimes not possible at all. Unified Workspace That Adapts to Your Workflow

I find Notion most valuable for its unified workspace that integrates documents, databases, and task management in one environment. It supports flexible structuring of information, so I can design pages that match the way I think rather than conforming to a fixed template. The database features are particularly useful because they allow sorting, filtering, and linking across projects, which helps maintain consistency and reduces redundant work. The main limitation is performance when working with large databases or nested pages. Pages can load slowly, which disrupts workflow. Absolutely Love this Product

Notion is an all-in-one tool for my life. It helps me plan my highly stressful days as a project manager at a start up. I can put all my personal and work task in a customizable and flexible format which works great for someone who is looking for neurodiversity. It has a fun UI that makes me look forward to making updates and gives me a dopamine rush because I can get everything out of my head in a satisfying way due to how user friendly it is. It’s one of the few I can actually stick with and use daily because my brain relates to ut better than a notepad or Microsoft’s task lists/one note. It the formatting of watch tab is easy to use and fits my work and life in general. Best part is there is a freemium version. I wish they had a tab for a concept board where I can scribble down things and drop sticky notes beside it. In almost every area I love this tool otherwise. Powerful Yet Complex - Amazing Features

I like the fact that Notion feels quite simple to use, making it approachable even though it has a lot of complex capabilities under the hood. I appreciate how it allows me to set up automations and formulas that link with every form, providing a malleable system that adapts to my needs. This functionality is particularly handy as it helps me manage and link different projects together efficiently, especially when dealing with time constraints. The ability to set urgencies between projects and have everything come to a main dashboard and database is really valuable. It helps me accumulate a structured task plan for the day and ensures that if I've missed something, it flags it for me. This blend of simplicity and powerful automation makes Notion an impressive tool for organizing my business projects. I think there needs to be a simpler method into how one can set up these types of automations and formulas in Notion. While there is a lot of AI usage now, and I know there's a lot it can do, it would be much more helpful if there were templated examples of things it could do instead of having to let the user guess. Additionally, the initial setup was quite hard, as I didn't understand what I was doing or how to do it, so I had to use ChatGPT to guide me. Effortless Daily Planning and Productivity with Notion

Notion is the software that help us in planning our day much efficiently as it has different type of to-do lists, notes google docs, excel sheets etc where all the entries and data input can be noted down and executed according to priority. Notion helps us in utilising our daily working hour in a much better way When I installed notion for the first time I got confused because the software has too many planning features and tools for maintaining day to day tasks. I would recommend to team notion that they should also provide a training session for their new users who subscribe to their platform for business purposes. Centralize and Improve Information Management

I enjoy having everything in one place with Notion, which allows me to start with something very simple, like a text page, and then enhance it by adding tables, tasks, tags, and creating relationships between pages, as well as calendar and board views. This offers me a personalized way to organize my work. Additionally, I appreciate that the databases, templates, and the ability to establish relationships between pages work well, allowing me to structure my information efficiently. I also love the distraction-free writing option, which helps me concentrate better. I would say it could be the performance with many pages or databases, learning curve, mobile use, too much flexibility. Versatile and Intuitive, Yet Room for UX Improvements

I use Notion mainly for managing a knowledge database and have recently started using it for task management as well. I love how Notion is built like a brain, or at least like my brain, which makes organizing information intuitive and personalized. The high rotation of employees in my organization is a challenge, but the knowledge database feature ensures continuity and consistency over time. I also appreciate the availability of keyboard shortcuts, which streamline my workflow and make navigation quick and efficient. Additionally, I'm thrilled that Notion provides form services, which were a major reason for switching from Tally forms. I find the desktop app to be quite slow on my computer, which has low RAM, causing performance issues. I also dislike that the full width view is not the default setting for pages, and there is no option to set it as the default for the entire organization, hindering customization. The learning curve is steep, and I'd appreciate a more user-friendly experience for first-time users, specifically by allowing shared default settings for an entire workspace. Additionally, I find that the image preview functionality is inadequate, as it takes a considerable amount of time for images to load. Moreover, the integrations appear nebulous and are challenging to utilize effectively. Intuitive and Customizable Interface That Keeps Us Organized

The user interface. It’s easy to customize and organize. I’ve always had issues with other programs having a layout where either I get confused or I can’t find things, notion is clear and easy to read thus I can quickly understand what me and my team need to do. While it is a interactive interface I do with there were more way to discuss with my team members of in a direct way. It is still easy to message but it would be cool if there could be come integrations with services like zoom where we could a schedule meetings and have them through the website itself, really keeping everything within one contained area. A Flexible workspace that adapts to however our team wants to work

The embedding and linking features are outstanding: it's easy to link one page to another, drag and drop blocks, and create either a wiki or a task board with the same level of simplicity. This flexibility allows me to move seamlessly from brainstorming ideas to executing tasks, all within a single app. What I appreciate most is how the tool adapts to my needs, rather than forcing me to adapt to it. I can organize pages, databases, and links however I like Offline access works, but not as seamlessly as a native desktop app. Also, because the system is so flexible, different teams sometimes build pages in completely different styles unless we set a few internal guidelines. Effortless Team Communication, Anywhere

Very easy to use and stay connected with my team, even when working remote. I love that there is a mobile app to use on the go. The huddle feature sometimes is lagging. There's been times I have to answer on my mobile phone because no matter how many times I select to "Join" on my desktop, it doesn't let me into the huddle. It happens on and off, not too often. Slack: The Ultimate Hub for Seamless Team Collaboration and Integration

I'd like to acknowledge the crucial role that Slack plays in our daily staff operations. Slack is the undisputed champion of real-time team communication and has transformed how our internal teams execute work. The primary drawback of using Slack, which is widely cited and contrasts directly with its strength of "instantaneity," is notification overload and distraction, which can severely hurt employee productivity and focus. Effortless Communication and Organization with Slack

I love how slack keeps communication fast and transparent. The biggest thing that I dislike is the thread conversation/UI is not good, it is prone to miss out very easily. Slack: The Ultimate Hub for Seamless Workflows and Knowledge Integration

What really convinces me about Slack is how it brings together documentation and workflows through its ecosystem of bots and applications. We use Slack for much more than just chatting; it also allows us to interact directly with our knowledge base, such as Confluence or Notion. For example, we can use commands like /search-kb [term] right within a channel to find answers, eliminating the need to switch between different applications. This functionality, along with custom bots that handle simple tasks like launching quick polls or setting reminders, turns Slack into a centralized command hub for our company's information infrastructure. The primary challenge we encounter is managing internal automation workflows using Workflow Builder. Although the tool offers robust capabilities, its interface for constructing complex logic can be less intuitive and more restrictive than we would prefer. This often leads us to rely on code-based solutions for more sophisticated integrations. Additionally, the Canvases feature—persistent documents within Slack—is still developing and does not yet fully substitute for a dedicated documentation tool. As a result, we sometimes end up duplicating important information across different platforms. Slack Keeps My Team Connected and Productive

Slack makes communication fast, organized, and easy to manage. I like how channels keep conversations focused, and the search function makes it simple to find past messages, files, and updates. Integrations with tools like Google Drive, ClickUp, and Zoom also make it a central hub for daily work. It helps my team stay aligned without long email threads. The only downside is that Slack can get noisy when there are many channels and notifications. Messages can move quickly, and it’s easy to miss updates if you’re away for a short time. I’d also love more intelligent filtering or prioritization features to highlight the most important conversations. Enhances Business Communication Seamlessly

What I appreciate most about Slack is the way it keeps communication streamlined and organized. The use of channels allows for clear separation of projects and topics, which cuts down on clutter and ensures everyone remains informed. The interface is intuitive and responsive, making real-time conversations easy while also supporting focused, asynchronous work. Thanks to its robust integrations and dependable search functionality, Slack serves as a central hub where information, tools, and teams connect effortlessly. There is nothing i dislike about Slack, its enhances business communication. Centralized and Agile Communication for Teams

I like that I can centralize all team communication in one place, keeping everything organized by channels. Channels and direct messages are very useful because they allow me to separate topics and communicate quickly with whoever I need. This reduces the number of emails and promotes more agile and real-time communication. Additionally, project or team channels help keep conversations organized. Integrations with other tools also make daily work much easier. Sometimes, the number of messages can be overwhelming and it's easy to overlook something important. When there are too many channels and notifications without proper configuration, everything turns into noise. Receiving many notifications can be a distraction, and relevant topics can easily get lost among so many conversations. If the team doesn't use the tool in an organized way, it ends up becoming chaotic. Streamlining Communication and Boosting Efficiency: A Review of Slack

What I like best about Slack is how it centralizes communication in a way that keeps everything organized and easy to navigate. It allows teams to communicate in real-time, which is perfect for quick updates and collaboration. I also really appreciate how customizable it is—whether it’s through channels, direct messages, or integrations with other tools like Google Drive or Trello. The ability to have different channels for different projects or topics helps keep conversations focused, and the search feature is great for finding past discussions or files quickly. It’s super user-friendly, and the notifications let me stay on top of important messages without feeling overwhelmed. Overall, it just makes team communication smoother and more efficient. One thing I don’t like about Slack is how easily it can become overwhelming. With constant notifications, threads, and messages coming in from different channels, it can sometimes feel like a lot to keep up with, especially if you’re in a lot of active channels. It can get a bit chaotic, and if you're not careful with your notification settings, you might miss important messages or get distracted by too many minor updates. Also, while Slack is great for real-time communication, it can sometimes be hard to track long-term discussions or decisions, since threads can get buried in the flood of messages. Lastly, the integrations with other tools are helpful, but they can also add complexity, and sometimes those apps don’t work as smoothly as you’d like. It would be nice if there were ways to manage these things a bit more effectively. A seamless and efficient tool that keeps teams aligned.

What I like most about Slack is how seamlessly it keeps communication organized and fast. Channels make it easy to separate projects and teams, while direct messages streamline quick decision-making without getting lost in long email threads. Integrations with tools like Google Drive, Monday, and Zoom make collaboration effortless. Overall, Slack helps reduce noise, centralize updates, and keep everyone aligned in real time.One downside of Slack is that conversations can move very quickly, making it easy to miss important messages if you’re away for even a short time. Channels can also become cluttered when many people are active, which sometimes makes it harder to keep track of action items. Additionally, notifications can feel overwhelming without careful customization. While these issues are manageable, they can impact focus and require extra organization to stay on top of everything. One downside of Slack is that conversations can move very quickly, making it easy to miss important messages if you’re away for even a short time. Channels can also become cluttered when many people are active, which sometimes makes it harder to keep track of action items. Additionally, notifications can feel overwhelming without careful customization. While these issues are manageable, they can impact focus and require extra organization to stay on top of everything. All-in-One Productivity Platform with Seamless Integrations

Slack helps me stay productive because I can communicate, share files, and track tasks all in one platform. Integrations with tools like Jira, Google Drive, and Zoom save a lot of time and reduce unnecessary meetings Sometimes, Slack can become overwhelming, especially when several channels are active at once. It’s easy for important information to get lost among the conversations. I find it much more manageable when teams take the time to organize channels clearly and make good use of threads or pins to keep key details accessible. Unmatched Customization and Integration Powerhouse

The strongest advantage of Jira is how customizable and adaptable it is. Teams can modify workflows, screens, fields, and permissions to match exactly how their process works. Scrum teams benefit from its sprint boards, burndown charts, backlog grooming, and story point tracking. The ability to integrate with tools like GitHub, Bitbucket, Slack, Confluence, and CI/CD systems makes Jira a central hub for planning and tracking work from start to finish. Jira's biggest drawback is its complexity. The interface can be dense, especially for new users who see many menus and configuration options. Setting up workflows, screens, and custom rules might require deep knowledge or admin support. If a workspace has been poorly configured over time, Jira can become cluttered with unnecessary issue types, long forms, and confusing statuses. A reliable project management platform that keeps teams organized and on-track.

What I like most about Jira is how well it organizes the entire workflow for our team. Tasks, Bugs, sprints, everything stays in one place. The agile boards are extremely easy to follow, and it becomes clear very quickly who is working on what and where the bottlenecks are. The customization options are a big plus. You can design your own workflows, create custom issue types, and adapt Jira to match the team's style instead of forcing everyone into a fixed structure. Integrations are solid as well... IT connects smoothly with slick, github, Bitbucket, confluence and even design tools. I personally didn't integrated it with other software but the dev team and managing team had experience and they they have good feedback about it. Getting started was easier than expected, with ready-made project templates and guided setup our team and running quickly. The documentation and community support are impressive. Even when we had questions about workflow or automations, we found answers almost immediately. We used Jira almost daily.... from backlog grooming and sprint planning to tracking bugs and releases. It has basically become the backbone of our project workflow. The interface can feel overwhelming at first, I mean the first time I logged in it does feel like that. It took some time to get accustomed. Even our new team members who are not familiar with agile tools. Some advanced configurations also require more time to understand. Performance can slow down a bit with very large projects. Unmatched Flexibility and Customization for Agile Teams

The best part about Jira is its depth and flexibility. You can customize everything: workflows, issue types, fields, automations, permissions, and boards. This means a team can design Jira exactly the way their process works. The Agile boards are especially helpful for teams can plan sprints, track progress in real time, and manage backlogs with full visibility. The interface can feel overwhelming, especially for new team members. There are so many menus, configurations, and nested options that onboarding becomes difficult. Sometimes, even experienced users struggle to locate workflow settings or custom fields. When too many custom rules or automations are added, Jira can also slow down or become hard to maintain. Unmatched Flexibility and Customization for Engineering Teams

Jira's greatest strength is its flexibility and depth. Almost everything from workflows and statuses to issue types and automations can be customized based on a team's process. This level of configurability is extremely valuable for engineering teams with complex deliverables. Its sprint boards are powerful; teams can manage backlogs, estimate tasks, link related tickets, visualize work in progress, and track velocity trends. Jira's power can also be its weakness. For new users, the interface is complex and may feel overwhelming. Navigating boards, filters, workflows, and issue properties can be confusing until someone becomes familiar with the system. Highly customized workflows often create friction; too many statuses, transitions, or automation rules can slow down everyday usage. Unmatched Flexibility and Agile Support for Teams

Jira's strongest advantage is its flexibility. It allows teams to customize workflows, issue types, and boards to match any development or project style. Its support for Agile frameworks like Scrum and Kanban is excellents, making sprint planning, backlog grooming, and progress tracking extremely efficient. The detailed visibility it provides through dashboards, reports, and automation helps teams stay aligned and ensures that no task is lost or delayed. Because of its advanced features, Jira can feel overwhelming for new users. The interface is sometimes cluttered, and customizing workflows can become complicated without prior experience. Setting up permissions, screens, and transitions often requires admin knowledge. Additionally, Jira can feel heavy for smaller teams that don't need such a deep level of structure. Professional and efficient collaboration with Jira's digital features.

I like using Jira's virtual features and resources because it is a high performance platform for creating an effective and professional business collaboration space, allowing me to share my ideas and work projects with each member of my department. I can't think of anything negative about Jira's features and virtual resources, I like how it works technically and it's a platform I can recommend to all my colleagues. Jira made managing my tasks and projects much easier.

I now use Jira in my day-to-day activities since the manner of managing issues and projects makes it very convenient to me to be organised. Being able to have unlimited issues and projects ensures that I do not face any problems of reaching the limit and it has also been able to keep everything- small to long-term work- in a single location. I also heavily use the backlog and board views to plan my week and the timeline and calendar views have served me to plot deadlines without forgetting anything. This is likely to be the most beneficial aspect of the forms feature since I am able to gather the information about other teams without sending several messages. The establishment was not complex as well, the project templates and the customization of workflow saved my time a lot. I am now using Jira on a daily basis and when I became comfortable with the layout it was easy to navigate. It has also helped when it has been incorporated with Microsoft Teams, as updates and notifications are displayed where we communicate as a team, so nothing goes astray. I have already contacted the customer care a few times and they were able to respond quickly. The primary issue I have discovered with Jira is that initially it may seem somewhat overwhelming because of the available variety of features and views. It requires time to know how all things fit in and new users may end up lost in the menus or settings. Empowers Team Collaboration and Project Transparency

What I appreciate most about Jira is how it brings transparency to the whole development process. I find it especially helpful for team collaboration, tracking progress, and keeping everyone aware of priorities, blockers, and deadlines. The customizable workflows and dashboards also make managing even complex projects much more efficient. Jira offers a lot of power, but at times it seems overly complex for straightforward workflows. Navigating between boards, issues, and backlogs can be sluggish or involve more steps than expected. Additionally, when there are numerous fields and custom workflows, the interface tends to become cluttered, which makes it more challenging to maintain a clean and organized workspace. From Idea to Deploy: Finally a Workflow That Follows me, Not Vice-Versa

I like the views flexibility: board view for daily tasks, list view for backlog refinement, timeline view for roadmap planning. Switching feels natural and helps me see tasks from different angles. The scalability is impressive: As my blog, app dev and features workload grew, I didn't feel like I needed to move to a bigger tool - the same Jira instance handled extra epics, teams and integrations without breaking the flow. Customising reports and dashboards to match how we measure work (especially outside of standard dev metrics) sometimes required and add-on or extra plugin - so there's extra cost or work if you want deep custom analytics. A reliable tool for keeping project organized

I like most about is that once you get the hang of it , it is genuinely easy to use for managing daily task and tracking progress. The implementation is flexible and you can shape to match your teams workflow without too much trouble. I also appreciate the number of features it offers boards, sprint , reports automation there's a tool for almost everything. I use very frequently and it fits in smoothly with other tools so the integrations parts feels natural. Whenever i have needed help their customer support has been responsive and clear. It can feel overwhelming for new users because of the number of settings and configurations. Some parts of the ui also feel a bit slow when working on projects. Effortless Project Organization and Team Collaboration

I love how easy Asana makes it to organize projects, assign tasks, and keep everyone on the same page. The boards, timelines, and subtasks give me a clear picture of what’s in progress and what’s coming next. It’s especially helpful for managing multiple clients and deadlines at once, and the reminders and notifications make sure nothing slips through the cracks. Sometimes Asana can feel a bit overwhelming for new team members because there are so many views and options. A few features are slightly hidden in menus, so it can take a minute to figure out where things are. It would also be nice if reporting and time-tracking were more robust without needing extra integrations. Overall, the benefits still far outweigh these small drawbacks. Effortless Organization and Team Coordination

I really appreciate how user-friendly Asana is. Learning to use it was quick and straightforward, which is a big plus because it saves us from needing any formal training sessions, making the initial setup a breeze. This ease of use is particularly beneficial when onboarding new team members, as they can start using the platform without any hassle—it's truly plug-and-play friendly. I find the quick and easy setup invaluable for my organization, streamlining our processes effectively. On top of that, I think the functionality of Asana is perfect, meeting all my productivity needs flawlessly. My preference for the app over the web version shows just how well the application performs for me. I'm so satisfied with Asana that I would rate my likelihood of recommending it to a friend or colleague a solid 10. My only gripe is that when I open Asana tasks via email, it doesn't open in the app. I prefer using the app over the web version. Easy Integration, But Task Assignment Limits

I appreciate how Asana's API is more user-friendly with higher rate limits, which significantly enhances my workflow by allowing the uploading of larger batches of data efficiently. The ease of data replication through Asana due to the integration with my replication vendor is a major advantage. I find the initial setup of Asana to be very easy, which helped me transition to using the software with minimal effort and inconvenience. The ability to use Asana in tandem with other tools like Stitchdata and Airflow for data replication and orchestration seamlessly fits into my work processes, making the entire experience smooth and efficient. I dislike that Asana does not allow assigning multiple people to tasks, which is a limitation in cases where collaboration from team members across different departments is necessary. Essential for Remote Team Collaboration, but Requires Extensive Onboarding

I appreciate how Asana helps keep our team connected, even though we all work remotely for a significant portion of the week. It enables us to communicate in real time as we progress through different projects, making it invaluable for our creative collaboration across all departments in a small nonprofit. I love that Asana makes it very easy for our team to stay focused and connected on complex and lengthy tasks. It's a great platform for direct communication and allows us to champion each other's work as we go through projects together. I find the onboarding process for Asana quite challenging, as it takes a significant amount of time and effort to train the entire team, especially given their varying skill sets. It required dedicated team members to focus on this as part of their job for several weeks. While Asana is a robust platform, this complexity in initial training could be a potential concern for new users or teams considering adopting it. Efficient Task Management but UI Needs Improvement

I find Asana to be an excellent project management tool that greatly enhances team collaboration and efficiency. It allows us to create, track, and optimize the workflow of any project with ease. The ability to divide big tasks into smaller, manageable ones is particularly valuable to me, as it helps streamline the process and ensure tasks are completed efficiently. The platform's feature of assigning tasks to specific team members enhances accountability, ensuring that everyone remains on top of their responsibilities. Furthermore, I appreciate the Asana app integrated with Microsoft Teams, as it consolidates all relevant information and notifications into a single platform, making it easier to stay updated. I also found Asana’s instructional system remarkably effective, making the learning process seamless and ensuring a smooth transition for the team when we first started using the tool years ago. I dislike that the interface could be more friendly, especially regarding color choices, as it might not be visually appealing to all users. Additionally, the location of some buttons can be confusing, which may disrupt the workflow and add unnecessary complexity to navigation. Intuitive Interface and Customizable Views Make Project Management a Breeze

One of the things I like most about Asana is its clean, intuitive interface. It makes project management feel less overwhelming by breaking things down into manageable tasks and sub-tasks. Plus, the ability to customize views (like boards, lists, and timelines) makes it versatile for different workflows. At the moment, I don't have a things to dislike since I am still new to Asana, but so far I am enjoying my experience with it. Great for Team Organization and Project Tracking

I really like how Asana makes it easy to organize and track projects in one central place. The interface is intuitive, and features like task assignments, due dates, and project timelines help keep everyone accountable and on the same page. The ability to integrate with other tools (like Slack, Google Drive, and Zoom) is also super helpful. Overall, it improves team communication, boosts productivity, and ensures that deadlines don’t slip through the cracks. One downside of Asana is that it can feel a bit overwhelming at first, especially for new users who aren’t familiar with project management tools. There are so many features and views that it takes time to learn how to use them effectively. It can also get cluttered if projects aren’t well organized, and some advanced features are only available in paid plans. Additionally, notifications can become excessive if not managed properly, which sometimes makes it harder to focus. Keeps Our Projects on Track

Asana is great for keeping projects organized and tracking team tasks. The interface is clean and intuitive, and the notifications make sure nothing gets forgotten. I really like the subtasks and dependencies feature — it helps a lot with prioritizing and meeting deadlines. The integrations with Google Drive and Slack also make the daily workflow much smoother. Sometimes Asana can feel a bit overwhelming when managing multiple large projects at once. There are many features, and it can take time for new users to learn how to use them effectively. Also, the mobile app is less fluid than the desktop version, especially when editing or reorganizing tasks. Customizable and Efficient, But Exporting Data Needs Improvement

I appreciate being able to add my own custom fields and tags, which work well together. It's simple to set up workflows that minimize the need to recreate tasks or manually mark them as 'completed.' The customizable forms are also excellent, making it easy to add new tasks. Exporting information from projects can be quite a hassle. I use this tool to keep track of OHS items and meeting minutes, but when I export the data as a CSV file, I still need to manually adjust it to make it more legible. Great for Scalability, but Initial Learning Curve for New Users

As a Marketing Manager juggling multiple campaigns, content calendars, and cross-departmental collaborations, Asana has become the central hub that keeps everything on track. After years of using various project management tools, I can confidently say that Asana strikes the ideal balance between structure and flexibility, empowering both strategic planning and daily execution. For new users, Asana’s feature set can feel a bit overwhelming. However, once the structure is established, especially with thoughtful naming conventions and templates, it becomes intuitive and highly scalable. The mobile app is excellent for on-the-go updates and quick check-ins during meetings or site visits. Intuitive and User-Friendly Platform That Simplifies Planning

Easy to use, not full of colours and big boxes like other products, you can see your plan on one page. It's intuitive easy for people to understand after just 5 minutes of coaching. Collaborative working works well in the most part with live updates when two people are on the same sheet. I do not like the new licencing model, it has created another level of administration and fear of breaching member accounts. What was almost a USP over other products that everyone didn't need to be licenced and a clear direction of where Smartsheet is heading. The whole new licencing model is also not very straight forward. Smartsheet Modernized Our Workflow and Boosted Team Collaboration

The collaboration within the team has improved significantly. I also find the filters to be very useful. We moved our trackers from Excel to Smartsheet, and it works much better now, even in terms of how it feels to use. I have to say, the forms have made things a lot easier for us. I really like the tick boxes - something soo simple, but makes a bit difference. I like the little details like the dates function - It's just a lot more modern than our excel sheet. Some Excel keyboard shortcuts don’t always work — for example, Ctrl+D (which should fill down like in Excel) often doesn’t do anything. Unmatched Flexibility Lets Every Team Work Their Way

What we’ve come to appreciate most about Smartsheet is how flexible it is. Unlike traditional project management software that locks you into one rigid format, Smartsheet gives you the freedom to design your own workflows — whether that’s through grids, Gantt charts, calendars, or dashboards. For ISDM, this flexibility means that each team can adapt Smartsheet to its own needs while still maintaining a shared language of progress and accountability. For instance, our academic team uses it to plan program calendars and track course deliveries, while our communications team uses it to manage campaigns, content pipelines, and deadlines. it can sometimes feel complex for new users. The learning curve can be steep for team members who aren’t used to project management systems or formula-driven sheets. We’ve found that onboarding and consistent training are key to getting everyone comfortable. Similarly, as our use of Smartsheet has expanded, licensing costs have become something to watch — the platform is worth the investment, but it’s not cheap if you want advanced features for every team member. Smartsheet Streamlines Task Management with Helpful Intake Forms

Smartsheet has been very useful for organizing my tasks, especially with the intake form, which makes the process much smoother. The steps it provides are genuinely helpful for tracking the progress and current stage of my team's tickets. There isn't much to comment on overall, but I did notice one thing: I have to click 'save' every time I make changes to the sheet. An auto-save feature would have been much more convenient. Unmatched Flexibility Makes It Stand Out

I use this solution several times a week. I particularly appreciate the ability to customize the Gantt view as well as the project view. The additional resource management module is also interesting, although it's unfortunate that you have to pay extra to benefit from it. The basic features are quite easy to grasp. However, for complete mastery, it's necessary to watch some training videos. I should note that I did not participate in the implementation or integration of the solution. I consider this solution to be quite expensive compared to other options available on the market. Additionally, customer service could also be improved. SmartSheet has become an essential part of my workflow

I’ve been using SmartSheet for 4–5 years to coordinate projects across multiple departments, and I have to say the experience has been surprisingly positive. It has gone through several upgrades over time. What I like most is the combination of a spreadsheet-style interface and automation features — it’s like using Excel, but with a brain that understands workflow. The interface design could be improved a bit, but that’s mostly a matter of personal preference, so it doesn’t really affect my overall impression or rating of the app. Effortless Project Management with Smartsheet’s Intuitive Interface

What I like best about Smartsheet is its user-friendly interface and intuitive design. Even though I’m not PMP-certified, I find it very easy to build, track, and manage complex projects. The platform allows me to visualize timelines, assign responsibilities, and follow progress without needing deep technical or project management expertise. It truly simplifies project coordination and keeps everything organized in one place. The navigation within columns can sometimes be distracting compared to Excel. Whenever I need to check specific details or analyze data more closely, I often end up exporting the sheet to Excel to do it there. Ideally, Smartsheet should allow for a smoother and more flexible in-platform data review experience, so everything can be done directly without the need for exporting. Versatile and Intuitive, but Formula Building Needs Simplifying

I truly love how versatile it is. It suits all of our information management needs and has become our one stop shop for multiple departments - it has really helped to provide support to all levels of experience and express it in a way that is creative yet intuitive The formula building can be a bit daunting to begin with. I would love it if there was a more simple formula building function as currently I tend to visit the community support section. Easy Collaboration for Project Management Teams

Smartsheet is straightforward to use and features an intuitive, user-friendly interface. I work with multiple sheets every day, and I appreciate being able to share them with both customers and coworkers while controlling their access permissions. This functionality helps me keep my projects on track and minimizes mistakes or the confusion that can come from too many people being involved. I find it challenging to adjust the size of rows and columns, and I wish there were an option to do so more easily. Additionally, starting a new sheet from a blank template is not very straightforward for me. I find it much simpler to create a new sheet by duplicating an existing Smartsheet. Great for Basic Use, Needs Excel-Like Shortcuts

I appreciate that Smartsheet acts as a dynamic, updated online tool that avoids the need to resend Excel files after every update. I love how it maintains some of the keyboard shortcuts from Excel, making certain tasks intuitive. I find the reminder feature invaluable for managing long-term tasks, sending me email alerts when needed. Adding notes to lines is intuitive, allowing multiple collaborators to update with timestamps, enhancing teamwork. The affordability and utility of basic features are ideal for our small sales team, making it a practical choice. I find it challenging that Smartsheet's keyboard shortcuts differ from Microsoft Excel, particularly with basic functions like copying and pasting. This inconsistency can be frustrating, especially since I'm used to Excel's interface. Additionally, the limitation on copying and pasting only 500 rows at a time is problematic for my work, especially after an acquisition that increased the number of parts we manage. Also, the control functions for actions like cut and paste aren't always aligned with Excel, which complicates my workflow since I frequently use these features. Seamless Team Management and Intuitive Interface

I love the user interface of monday Work Management; it's slick and aesthetically pleasing, making the platform more enjoyable to use. This ease of use significantly reduces the barrier to adoption within my team, driving better engagement because anyone can quickly pick it up and understand how it works. The various filtering options available are incredibly useful, allowing me to organize workspaces in multiple ways to suit different team needs, which is invaluable for efficient 1:1s and team meetings. Furthermore, the initial setup of monday Work Management was very easy due to its intuitive nature and the availability of numerous helpful tutorial videos. Additionally, compared to our previous tool, Jira, monday Work Management is far more user-friendly and accessible to all user groups, not just developers. With the addition of Monday.com Development, the platform now effectively fulfills all our requirements that were previously handled by Jira. There is nothing I dislike. End-to-End Workflow Automation Made Easy with monday Work Management

monday Work Management provides an extremely flexible and scalable foundation for building any workflow—without needing heavy custom development. Some advanced automations still require custom coding or external services, especially when handling large datasets or complex conditional logic. Versatile, Intuitive, and Essential for Project Management

I've used Monday for about 8 years now and it's proven to be one of the most useful, versatile, and intuitive tools I use in my day-to-day. Boards are easy to use with powerful customization and workflow automations. Gantt and calendar views with eye catching and flexible features make visualizing projects and jobs-to-be done easy and attractive. It's minor, but having word processing options within make it really easy to set up a workspace that contains both list/chart views and note/long-form text views in one space. Many ways to work to fit any team or team members preferences, all easily integrated in one space. Admin team and user management is also very intuitive. There's nothing to straight out dislike, but in terms of suggestions, it would ben nice if a gantt chart or calendar view could be built first and have the board prepopulate rather than other way around. Additional flexibility in those features would help as well (ways of viewing, zooming in/out etc.). The way folders work could be improved as well to help with board/file management - for example, right now if you move an item from one folder to another you expand all folders at once and have to re-collapse them all - little things like that. Intuitive Tool for Project Management

I absolutely love using monday Work Management as it is incredibly intuitive, making it easy for me to navigate and utilize effectively in my role as the Business Manager of a private school. The platform seamlessly integrates with other tools, particularly beneficial as we work extensively with the Google Suite, allowing us to attach all related documentation to each item in the platform with ease. The ready-to-use templates are a significant asset, thoughtfully designed to meet our needs and significantly reduce the time required to set up new boards for tracking student enrollment and various projects. Moreover, the ease of initial setup was simply remarkable, reinforcing the platform's user-friendly nature and efficiency. I have no major issues with Monday. Highly Customizable, But Needs Better Notifications

I like the ability to customize every board depending on the projects and on the needs. This customization makes it highly adaptable to various project requirements, enhancing my team’s efficiency. I also appreciate that it offers different types of views, which make it easier for everyone to focus on the aspects most relevant to their roles. Moreover, I like the feature that allows us to leave comments and updates, which keeps everyone aware of what's going on. This transparency and communication help streamline project management and ensure that no important details are missed. I think it would be better if monday Work Management had a more robust system for notifications. The current notification system can be quite weak, especially when connecting with Microsoft Teams. There are times it glitches, and as a result, notifications aren't sent, which means some updates can get lost. Effective CRM and Task Management, Needs Better Onboarding

I like the way monday Work Management keeps our CRM database very unique and understandable, which is crucial for keeping every team member on the same page. This ensures that we all stay informed and collaborate effectively. As part of the business development team, this clarity helps us keep track, systemize our countries, and manage our lead sources efficiently, especially since we are scouting fashion brands from all over the world. This organized approach streamlines our workflow and helps maintain consistency across our global operations. I feel that 'monday Work Management' can be difficult to understand and utilize to its full potential. This is mainly due to the challenge our team faces in comprehending the solution and features entirely. Although I appreciate the availability of webinars, more guidance would be helpful. Additionally, the initial setup was slightly challenging because our team consists of remote members across Europe, leading to difficulties in systemizing everyone on the same basis even though it wasn't directly a work management issue. An intuitive and flexible platform to keep all projects on track
What I like most about monday.com is how visual and easy to use it is. Not much. Streamlined Task Management with Room for AI Improvement

I like the flexibility of monday Work Management and the ability to adapt different goals according to a wide range of topics. This flexibility allows us to create boards tailored for various divisions, including one sitting abroad, alongside internal boards and those dedicated to specific tasks. This adaptability is crucial for us as it accommodates the diverse topics we deal with in our company. It’s actually quite a great feature, making the tool very practical and effective for task management across different business types. I find the limited use and implementation of the AI functions in monday Work Management notable. It seems that there is much room for improvement in effectively leveraging AI to create and manage tasks more efficiently. Additionally, the adaptation period requires a shift in how people approach task management, moving away from double tasking with other tools like Excel and emails. This change requires time for users to fully transition to using monday Work Management as the primary tool. Intuitive, Customisable Layout Makes Organising My Work Simple

The visual layout allows me to quickly see where everything stands at a glance for me and my team. I also appreciate that it is sortable, customisable, and very easy to use so onboarding new staff is uncomplicated for the basic features. I use monday every single day to keep track of projects, tasks and my team. The only issue I have is that I’m required to use the same status categories in a column within a board. There are times when I want to track the same information within a single board, but the categories just aren’t relevant for all groups. This means I end up having to add unnecessary columns or even create additional boards to accommodate the differences. Intuitive, collaborative and enjoyable virtual environment to plan, execute and review our projects.

The vast array of tools/features and integrations that allow the different teams across the business to collaborate on projects together without miscommunication or confusion. Monday is intuitive, making it both easy to use and easy to implement across multiple teams of people. The only minor irritant when it comes to Monday.com is the navigation between workspaces, which fortunately isn't necessary alot of the time, as it can feel clunky to move to a workspace thqat is alternate to the main, or default workspace. A single platform that unifies work, reduces friction, and boosts team clarity

What I like most is how much I can centralise in a single place: tasks, documents, discussions, deadlines and dashboards for different projects and teams. The hierarchy (Workspaces → Spaces → Folders → Lists → Tasks), custom fields and views (List, Board, Gantt, etc.) let me adapt ClickUp to very different workflows without needing separate tools. It’s also great for collaborative work: comments, assigned comments, checklists and automations make it much easier to follow who is doing what and keep complex projects under control. Sometimes the flexibility comes with complexity: new users can feel overwhelmed by the number of options and configuration screens. These aren’t deal-breakers, but they are areas where there is still room for improvement. ClickUp brought clarity and structure to our cross-team operations

What I love most about ClickUp is how seamlessly everything works together. The combination of Chat, Whiteboards, and Spaces allows us to brainstorm, assign, and track work all in one place. It’s flexible, visual, and highly customizable perfect for managing multiple teams and projects across departments. The Wiki feature also helped us replace scattered SOPs and onboarding docs with a single source of truth. The learning curve can be steep for new users, especially when trying to navigate the depth of features without guidance. Some team members found it overwhelming at first. Also, while the mobile app is useful, it’s not yet as fluid or complete as the desktop version. A few UI refinements could improve speed and intuitiveness overall. Clickup is what Jira had to do, but didn't

The new UI doesn't look that bad. Even when it's a "Notion-like" UI, it works a little faster, and it has implemented new features that are pretty cool, like AI, or docs, or whiteboards... Everything in a single place is pretty useful. It's still noisy as hell, too many apps, too many places, too many features, so it's now a Slack, Docs, Jira, Trello, Monday, Idontknowwhatelse, and it feels too much, when we just want to handle some simple projects, it feels like we are going in a labyrinth of buttons and clicks... Boosted productivity with Brain MAX

The new Brain MAX has greatly enhanced my productivity. The ability to use multiple AI models, including advanced reasoning models, for an affordable price makes it easy to centralize everything in one platform. Features like voice-to-text, task automation, and integration with other apps make the workflow much smoother and smarter. Despite the improvements, performance can be a bit heavy on older computers, especially when using multiple automations and AI features simultaneously. Also, the initial learning curve can be a bit challenging for new users. One Workspace to Rule My Tasks -- With a Bit of Setup Upfront.

For someone working solo/small team (like me Android/Kotlin Solo Traveler project scope), the free/mid-tier capabilities feel generous -- I could start without big cost and grow as needed. The major win for me is how ClickUp lets me see everything in one place, Tasks, Docs, Goals, Calendar, Boards -- so i rarely feel like I'm "jumping between apps". And the integrations with tools I already use reduced friction in our dev + blogging + team communications workflow. Sometimes the UI feels busty: with so many options, buttons and views, many nested project or hefty automations -- on slower hardware/browser I noticed a bit of lag. Highly recommend Brain MAX for anyone serious about boosting productivity and clarity!

ClickUp Brain MAX has been an incredible addition to my workflow. The way it combines multiple LLMs in one platform makes responses faster and more reliable, and the speech-to-text across the platform is a huge time-saver. I also really appreciate the enterprise-grade security, which gives peace of mind when handling sensitive information. Because ClickUp is packed with features, customization options, and different views (lists, boards, Gantt, etc.), it can be overwhelming at first. New users often need considerable time to become comfortable and productive. ClickUp: Revolutionized Our Task Management

I love the ease of use of ClickUp, especially in creating and customizing tasks, as I can adapt them exactly to my needs. The ability to integrate apps, organize in lists, set priorities, create columns, and fully customize tasks allows me to have a unique management experience. Furthermore, ClickUp efficiently solves task management, deadlines, and priority issues, which simplifies my life, both personal and professional. The integration with other tools, such as time apps and Google tools, also enhances my productivity and simplifies my routine. The transition to ClickUp from Trello and Google Tasks made my life much easier, as it centralizes everything on a single platform, from task management to document and spreadsheet organization. The initial setup process was facilitated by resources like YouTube videos and the official blog, but the support I received when I migrated to the paid plan was incredible, offering video conferences and tips, which further improved my usability on the platform. This effective support and the continuous development of new features that meet my needs, even those I wasn't always aware of, make ClickUp an indisputable choice. There is nothing I dislike about the platform, as it meets all my needs. ClickUp: A Robust Project Management Tool That Grows with You

ClickUp excels in its versatility and all-in-one approach to project management. It's became our organization's most frequently used app. It brings together task management, document creation, time tracking, goals, and collaboration tools in one unified interface which provides ease of implementation. The customization options are a standout, from custom views and statuses to automation and dashboards. It’s highly scalable, making it suitable for individuals, small teams, and large organizations alike. The interface is sleek, and features like recurring tasks, integrations with different tools , and the “Everything” view really streamline workflow management. ClickUp chat features are good but lags message delivery. Performance can sometimes lag when managing large workspaces or switching between views. Powerful and Flexible, but with a bit of a learning curve.

The best thing about ClickUp is its incredible flexibility and customizability. You can really tailor it to fit any workflow or project management style. The ability to create custom views, dashboards, and fields is amazing. I also love the wide range of features it offers, from task management and time tracking to document collaboration and goal setting. It's truly an all-in-one workspace. The sheer number of features can be overwhelming at first. It takes some time to learn the platform and figure out the best way to set things up for your team. The mobile app, while functional, could be more streamlined. Also, occasionally, performance can be a little sluggish, especially when dealing with large lists or complex dashboards. Intuitive and Essential, But Upset by Feature Paywall

It's intuitive, easy and fast to do what I need to do. I think it truly lives up to it's promise of minimizing clicks! I don't ever feel frustrated with the tool or think "why can't I just do xyz?" I like that I am able to report on time tracked and to view my tasks by due date, so that with multiple clients (and my own personal stuff) I am able to view only what I need to for that day. I literally could not do my job or keep track of any of my own stuff without this tool. And it's SO affordable! I don't like that a couple of timetracking features I have always used (time tags and time notes) were recently turned into Business features. So now, even though I'm already on a paid plan and I'm just a single-user instance, I now have to pay for the Business Plan just to get those two features, and I feel like I'm paying for a lot of other stuff I won't ever need now. Airtable: The Ultimate Upgrade from Excel for Streamlined Data Management

Airtable is a form of digital table where you can store data in different type of sheet and manage all them from one software. You can also add different type of formulas to filter the data from the seat according to your personal need and save a lot of time. It is an upgraded version of Excel according to my experience. Airtable is quite difficult to manage for large set of data and if you want to manage different type of projects all together then you might need to buy it subscription plan because features of free plan is not sufficient for day to day business purpose needs. Airtable: The Ultimate All-in-One Dashboard for Business Management

Airtable is a software that has multiple rows and columns and it help us in maintaining our inventories well and also handle our financial balance sheet regularly. This is a platform which handle all the database of our company in a single dashboard and work like a excel sheet for our business. According to my experience airtable lacks range of formulas unlike MS Excel for compiling all the data which are being entered into its sheets during the data entry process also the analysis data is not that much detailed in comparison with google sheet and advance excel that I have used before. Spreadsheet Ease Meets App-builder freedom - Perfect Blend, Some Trade-Offs

I really appreciate how Airtable makes it easy to build something more than a vanilla spreadsheet: linking tables, choosing field types (attachments, dropdowns, checkboxes), and then visualising the data in grids, calendars, Kanban boards - it gives me flexibility without jumping into full database dev. The fact that I didn't need to code to start is a big plus: within hours I had prototypes running, collating blog ideas, app features, marketing tasks - which for a solo dev/blogger workflow matters a lot. While the "views" and flexibility are strong, setting up a well-structured, maintainable base takes though: if you don't define conventions early (naming fields, designing relationships, orchestrating automations), the base can become messy and harder to manage. Airtable: Advanced Features and Seamless Automation

I have been using Airtable for more than 3 years now and this is one of the most advanced spreadsheet that I have ever used. The software is packed with different type of table management features and you can also add photos and videos to these documents. The software helps us in sending regular reminders and emails to our all the latest leads automatically. As learning each and every feature of Google sheet and MS Excel was already a difficult task earlier and the struggle is same with airtable and mostly for new users because learning it's all the usability is slow and time taking process. You will need a proper training session of more than 45 days to learn each and every feature and work perfectly by taking its optimum benefits. Airtable: Centralized Data Management with Flexible Views and Seamless Integrations

1. I like the fact that Airtable can be used as the central foundation for storing data coming in from different sources and manage them in different tables. 1. Pricing is a bit overwhelming.Free and lower plans have imposed limits on storign the multi media files that can be a bottleneck. Expensive and Less User-Friendly Than Asana, Lacking Task Completion tick button
- Ease of integration, yes - There is no ticking project to complete, you have to update the status by selecting Airtable Amazing tool

It is a great platform can be used as an excel and project management tool all in one place. Workspaces and templates and everything can be created with AI. Easy to use and manage projects and assign tasks with deadlines to people in teams. The tables are easy to make and manage and link across different tables. The automatics per month are limited and price per user is a bit much for what it offers. The platform requires introduction to new people as it gets complex with time and multiple projects, it tends to have a lot of learnings to do Improving Efficiency with Airtable AI

This platform makes us so powerful without even knowing much knowledge of Coding. There are no rigid templates but it can be created with just the AI tool which makes this platform very powerful and robust. The Capacity to integrate its platform is a big help while using this platform. I love the easy to login feature and user friendly Interface. The Automation feature of this platform is astounding. It will make user very effective with some learning. The pipelining is so good that there is hardly any chance that any project deadline will be missed. I am satisfied with its robust feature but to very effective and efficient in using this software, one must do a lot of learning. I feel that the platform is little bit slow while implementing on my browser but it is manageable. I also wish that the cost of the Platform is a little lower that the current pricing. Airtable Makes Data Management Effortless and Secure

irtable is such a systematic tool — it offers amazing ways to organize and manage data. I’ve been using it for a year now, and I’m completely used to it. Unlike Google Sheets or Excel, there’s almost less risk of anyone messing up the data. The only thing I don’t like is that it doesn’t show who made the last changes. Or maybe I just haven’t found that option on my dashboard yet. From Beginners to Advanced Users

AirTable can do as much or as little as you'd like. It can be a glorified Excel document or it can be a full project management system with automation and user interfaces. When you start to get into the more complex uses of AirTable and have multiple users, training and a general understanding is required. We also have to be weary of how people are using it, because someone could add something that breaks something else. brief experience, moved on quickly

i liked the organization and ability to view tasks and organize my tasks and projects as well as have my teamwork on various projects. i used the free plan which is very limited Its good for maybe personal task management, ut not for much more. overall i liked it, but many features are behind a paywall where on ClickUp its all free (and cheaper to upgrade). take a look at my review on ClickUp for more. I havent used it in a while, i tend to use clickup more than anything now A Single Source of Truth

We implemented Wrike in our creative agency over three years ago, and it has transformed the way we manage work. What started as a tool to streamline project intake quickly became the backbone of our operations. Wrike allows us to centralize requests, track projects from start to finish, and create greater visibility across teams through dashboards and reporting. My only complaint is that I have failed to see new features and tools released as requested by the community. There are huge threads of customers asking to see certain features implemented, and the Wrike team always assures us they're being worked on. I recently searched for a solution and discovered that someone had asked for the same feature to be built once monthly since 2017. Streamlines Team Management with Useful Workload Features

I find the workload and effort features in Wrike immensely useful for managing projects within our marketing agency. As a creative team member, these features help our project management team understand when people are overloaded and identify who can handle additional responsibilities. This significantly assists in organizing teams, scheduling work, and managing workloads efficiently across the agency. Having used Wrike for nearly 20 years, we have integrated these and more features deeply into our working methods, which enhances our overall productivity and organization. I think one of the biggest issues I face with Wrike is the absence of workload views on an iPad. I use the iPad sometimes as a secondary platform to view Wrike when I'm working, and it's not very easy to do so without the workload view. Uncluttered dashboard makes it easy to use once you get used to the layout

Wrike has an uncluttered dashboard that allows us to see pending tasks and who needs to handle specific task. It is easy to move or reorder tasks to suit our workflow. I also appreciate their sales people who were ready to help when we switched to Wrike. Key features are hidden behind small icons and dropdown menus such that you have to click around before you get used to the dashboard. when assigning tasks or adding due date beginners might struggle to find the tiny dropdown buttons. I also missed notifications becauss they don't really grab attention. I always had to doublecheck if someone left a message or comment. Boosts Team Collaboration, Smart Integrations

I appreciate how Wrike empowers my team to collaborate efficiently, allowing us to deliver projects faster. What I like most about Wrike is its ability to boost productivity and reduce manual work significantly once one understands its full potential. The integration with Outlook and MS Teams is a standout feature, saving us hours every day by keeping everything centralized. I can effortlessly turn emails or chats into tasks instantly, helping me stay on top of projects without the hassle of constantly switching between applications. Additionally, Wrike's AI feature was a crucial reason for our switch from Teamwork, showcasing its ability to innovate and stay ahead. The competitive pricing and outstanding support team further add to the experience, making Wrike a compelling choice for our project management needs. I find the mobile app to have limitations compared to the desktop version. It's useful for quick updates but is less intuitive and lacks some functionalities. Customizable Workflows and Support Make Wrike Feel Like Our Own

I appreciate Wrike because it allows us to customize our workflow and adjust it over time to create the ideal platform. Over time it feels like it we designed it ourselves. The customer care team was helpful when we were starting out. I feel it is not for people who are new to project management tools. It might feel overwhelming if you join an ongoing project setup by others. It will take time to learn and get used. I also feel all the team members have the power to mess the workflow. Wrike - The Best Project Management Tool

Wrike’s standout feature is its versatile views, resembling a spreadsheet but with the advantage of being online. It simplifies project management and makes progress tracking effortless. A key benefit is the ability to assign tasks to specific users and monitor their status within a single platform. Wrike enhances workflow efficiency while delivering accurate, high-quality data. It’s user-friendly, and the online support team is consistently helpful and reliable. Honestly, there's nothing I don't like about Wrike. A great tool for management and organization across all project sizes

What I like the most about Write is the high level of customization it offers for each project. You can easily set the level of communication and collaboration with co-workers or team members, which makes it adaptable for small, medium, and large projects. The user interface is smooth, clear, and very intuitive. It’s also easy to use, and customer support is responsive and helpful. I especially value the built-in features like project risk tracking, Gantt charts that automatically update tasks, and the ability to assign specific tasks to the right people. The recent addition of AI capabilities makes the tool even more powerful and forward-looking. Because there are so many features and options available, it can feel overwhelming at first. For new users, a simpler starting view or setup could make the onboarding process easier. Once you get familiar with the platform, however, it becomes much easier to navigate and take advantage of all the features. Wrike: Easy to Use, Excellent Support, Best Management Platform

Currently, Wrike is the best Management platform in the market. Its super easy to use, lots of online support and help is available and its easy to implement in work place. Pricing options and safety features are still concerning. My organization still doubts about complete functionality A great tool to organize your Tasks and Projects every day

Wrike has been a key tool in organizing my individual work and coordinating with my team. I use it in my daily routine, and it has become a fundamental part of my work routine. What I highlight the most is its intuitive interface, which allows for quick adaptation without the need for an extensive learning curve. From the first use, managing tasks, projects, and assignments becomes very smooth. Although in general I find Wrike to be an excellent tool, there are some details that could be improved to make the experience even smoother. One of the aspects that complicates things for me the most is when I change a task's status within the workflow. Sometimes, after dragging a task to a new column (for example, from "In Progress" to "Completed"), I can't immediately see it in its new status. This creates some uncertainty, as it makes me doubt whether the change was really saved or if the task ended up in the right place.
